['Theism - belief in one or more deities as the creators and rulers of the universe.', 'Atheism - disbelief or lack of belief in the existence of God or gods.', 'Agnosticism - view that the truth value of certain claims, particularly metaphysical ones, is unknown or unknowable.', 'Pantheism - a religious belief or worldview which holds that the universe (nature) and God are identical.', 'Monotheism - the doctrine or belief that there is only one deity.', 'Polytheism - the worship of or belief in multiple gods or deities.', 'Deism - an intellectual movement that emerged in England, stressing reason and observation as primary sources for knowledge about the natural and physical universe over revelation (which was received by those who were religious).', 'Pandeism - a blend between pantheism and deism which proposes that God became the universe and stopped existing as a separate entity.', "Dualism - the doctrine that two fundamental substances exist, typically 'mind' and 'matter'.", 'Idealism - belief or philosophy holding that reality, truth, or existence is mentally constructed or otherwise immaterial.', 'Realism (philosophy) - a philosophical position which holds that reality exists independently of observers.', 'Rationalism - the epistemological view that regards reason as the chief source and test of knowledge.', 'Empiricism - a theory that states that knowledge comes only or primarily from sensory experience.', 'Existentialism - a philosophical movement which emphasizes individual existence, freedom, and choice.', 'Nihilism - the rejection of all religious and moral principles, often in the belief that life is meaningless.', 'Materialism - an ontological theory or doctrine holding that nothing exists except matter and its movements and modifications.', 'Substance Dualism - a philosophical viewpoint that asserts two kinds of substance: mental and material, or mind and body.', 'Mind-body Dualism - the belief in the dual nature of reality â€“ where the world is composed of both physical matter (the body) and nonphysical aspects like thoughts, feelings, consciousness (the mind).', "Ethical Relativism - a theory that holds that morality is relative to the norms of one's culture or society rather than being universal.", 'Objectivism - a philosophy founded by Ayn Rand which asserts that there is an objective reality, and rational self-interest underlies moral behavior.']

['Crash - A violent collision or abrupt failure.', 'Breakdown - The sudden malfunctioning of a machine, system, or mechanism.', 'Collapse - The sudden falling inwards or downwards; to give way under pressure or weight.', 'Fumble - To fail clumsily at handling something, resulting in disarray and potential collapse.', 'Snap - A sharp, loud break caused by excessive force or tension.', 'Flatten - The act of pressing flat against a surface until it loses structure, potentially leading to complete collapse.', 'Give way - To stop resisting pressure and yield suddenly under weight or stress.', 'Buckle - A sudden folding inward due to overcrowding or excessive force, often associated with structural failure.', 'Tumble - Fall quickly and uncontrollably; can lead to disorderly collapse if not controlled.', 'Fray - To wear out by repeated use; the edge becomes weakened and may fray apart suddenly under strain.', 'Shatter - To break or smash violently into pieces, often resulting in sudden and complete destruction.', 'Disintegrate - Break or crumble into small fragments rapidly and completely.', 'Fracture - A crack or break in a solid material that can result in structural failure if not repaited.', 'Topple - Overturn or fall forwards, especially as a consequence of instability; may lead to complete collapse.', 'Disarray - A state of confusion and lack of order that could precede total disintegration.', 'Malfunction - Failure of a machine or system to function properly, potentially leading to an abrupt breakdown.', 'Conk - To suddenly fail; synonymous with collapsing under pressure.', 'Disintegrate - Break down completely into small parts; can be used interchangeably with disarray and fray in this context.', 'Crumble - Fall apart or break into pieces, potentially leading to a collapse if the structure is significant enough.', 'Sink - To fall suddenly or rapidly to a lower level; not always related to structural collapse but can metaphorically represent it when applied to businesses or economies.']
